children.subject: should we have significant exp with linear algebra before taking 127, or is material from 16A/16B/Math 54 sufficient enough to take the class?

I haven't actually taken ee16a/b so I can't say for sure, but ee16a/b are the official listed prereqs so you should be fine. 

Math54 was pretty computational for me, and 127 is pretty high level proof based, so I don't think sole 54 would be enough, but 54 + 110 was great prep for me. (again you've satisfied the official prereqs so you should be good). 

Ranade also gave us a diagnostic exam (non graded) on the 2nd day of class and it was helpful for setting expectations!

Hi there anon, OP here thanks for the response! With what you are saying, how proof heavy is 127? Because with respect to lin alg, I’m fairly comfortable with the computational aspect of lin alg covered in 16A and in 16B so far, but the proofs are always something I struggle in. Thanks again!

Data100 in sp20 is being taught by Prof Gonzalez and Professor Adhikari - a star duo for sure, so don't discount them instantly in favor of Hug!

I took EE127 in sp19 with Ranade and Bayen. I felt it was slightly on the higher end of upper division math courses in terms of workload, but still less than 189. The problem sets in my semester were weekly, which added a bit to the workload since you couldn't spread it out over 2 weeks, but that seems to be changing a lot per semester. The homework would take me about 8-10 hours per week, doable with time management and time spent in office hours. The homeworks were more work in the beginning of the semester (a lot of problems per pset) but after midterm feedback they lessened the number of questions per homework, which eased the load a bit. 

The course is challenging, as it is an upper division math minded course, but you seem to have a suitable math background. 

Overall I enjoyed 127!

I haven't taken 170 or 188, so can't speak to that.

Hi there anon, OP here. Thanks for the feedback! In terms of workload this semester I’m taking on 16B + 70 + Data8 + Philosophy 12A (a surprisingly technical humanities class!) . I guess I can say the workload is a good amount for sure, but it’s just those 16B problem sets that aren’t allowing me to fully absorb and appreciate the material in other classes. Are the problem sets of any of the above classes for next semester like that? Or is it like 70 where the problem sets aren’t super long, but each part of question requires some clever thought? And with the semester I have this semester, how does that make you feel about what I’m getting into for next semester? Thanks again for the insight!

Ok, that's a considerable workload for this semester. In that case I'd say it will only be a slight increase (mostly due to upper divs having less support, but also 127 and 170 are more on the difficult end).

170 and 127 can both be described as "problem sets aren’t super long, but each part of question requires some clever thought" :)

That being said, I think they are less intentionally tricky compared to CS70 (or perhaps CS70 just makes you stronger so you don't notice as much).

Ok cool then i think I’ll hang onto this for now. If it helps my case, I also plan on not doing any humanities/breadth class next semester so that I can maximize time to absorb the material in these classes and do well. And hopefully it also helps that I won’t have a 3 hour lab every week like 16B now + additional hours for car building. When you said it would be a slight increase in workload, was that including if I had taken a humanities next semester, or just in terms of the technicals? Thanks again so much for your input!

I imagine 170 + 188 + 127 will be a considerable increase in workload, unless you did something like 61b, 70 and 16b in one semester (and considering these will be your first upper divs?)

170+188 is a pretty common combo. 170 is about 70 level difficulty/workload, perhaps slightly easier/61b-esque. 188 is low workload, but deceptive in that the exams are relatively hard.

127 is about 170 level, slightly easier on the workload, but slightly harder on the difficulty. It doesn't have much support, so you will be on your own quite often (at least relative to other classes).

If you are good at or enjoy linear algebra, or have these type of classes before, this shouldn't be a problem.

Otherwise, I would not recommend doing all three at once.
yeah ive decided to drop 188 for this semester and just roll with 127 and 170. Hopefully that isn't too destructive for workload.

also keep in mind that 188/170 both have weekly psets. something to consider is taking 3 problem set classes at once vs taking 2 problem set classes and 1 project class. 3 problem sets due week can get old real quick haha

history.content:
Hi all, sophomore here looking for general advice from the community regarding the workload/difficulty of classes as enrollment comes up for next semester. By the end of this semester, in terms of technicals, I will have completed 61A, 61B, 70, EE16A and 16B, Math 1B and 53.

Next semester I was planning on taking CS170 with Professor Alessandro Chiesa and CS188 with Professor Sergey Levine for sure, but for the 3rd class I'm still debating. I either will take Data 100 or EECS 127 which is being taught by Professor Ranade.  I've heard enough about 170 and 188 to make a judgment but I'm always wanting to hear more to get as many views as I can. haven't heard enough about 127 to make that decision there. So I have a couple questions:

1. How are Cs170 and/or cs188 overall with respect to difficulty and workload, particularly under those professor's iterations, or just the courses overall if you didn't have them?

2. How is EECS 127, again in terms of difficulty and workload and with Professor Ranade if you had her, or any other iteration?

3. Is 170 + 188 + 127 manageable in a semester? I understand Data100 might be more manageable than 127 but as silly as it sounds I'm only pushing data100 out one semester because after taking 61B with hug, I want to take as many more hug classes as possible with data100 and 186 later down the line. But my original question still stands. 

Even if you've taken any of these classes individually and not altogether, I'd still appreciate any input. Thanks again for all your inputs!
history.subject: CS170 + CS188 + EECS127/Data100 workload and difficulty
